'''Floral scent''' or '''flower scent''' is composed of all the [[Volatile organic compound|volatile organic compounds (VOCs)]], or [[aroma compound]]s, emitted by floral tissue (e.g. flower petals). Floral scent is also referred to as '''aroma''', '''fragrance''', '''floral odour''' or '''perfume'''. Flower scent of most [[Flowering plant|flowering plant species]] encompass a diversity of VOCs, sometimes up to several hundred different compounds.<ref name="Knudsen_etal_2006">{{cite journal|last1=Knudsen|first1=Jette T.|last2=Eriksson|first2=Roger|last3=Gershenzon|first3=Jonathan|last4=Ståhl|first4=Bertil|title=Diversity and Distribution of Floral Scent|journal=The Botanical Review|date=March 2006|volume=72|issue=1|pages=1–120|doi=10.1663/0006-8101(2006)72[1:DADOFS]2.0.CO;2}}</ref><ref name="Piechulla&Effmert_2006">{{cite book|last1=Piechulla|first1=B.|last2=Effmert|first2=U.|title=Plant Developmental Biology - Biotechnological Perspectives|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=9783642046698|pages=189–205|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-3-642-04670-4_10|language=en|chapter=Biosynthesis and Regulation of Flower Scent}}</ref> The primary functions of floral scent are to deter [[Herbivore|herbivorous]] and especially florivorous insects (see [[Plant defense against herbivory]]), and to attract [[pollinator]]s. Floral scent is one of the most important communication channels mediating plant-pollinator interactions, along with visual cues (flower color, shape, etc.).<ref name="Raguso_2008">{{cite journal|last1=Raguso|first1=Robert A.|title=Wake Up and Smell the Roses: The Ecology and Evolution of Floral Scent|journal=Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics|date=December 2008|volume=39|issue=1|pages=549–569|doi=10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.38.091206.095601}}</ref>
[[File:Starr 071024-0039 Lonicera japonica.jpg|thumb|300px|Flowers of ''[[Lonicera japonica]]'' emit a sweet, subtle fragrance mainly composed of [[linalool]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=El-Sayed|first1=A. M.|last2=Mitchell|first2=V. J.|last3=McLaren|first3=G. F.|last4=Manning|first4=L. M.|last5=Bunn|first5=B.|last6=Suckling|first6=D. M.|title=Attraction of New Zealand Flower Thrips, Thrips obscuratus, to cis-Jasmone, a Volatile Identified from Japanese Honeysuckle Flowers|journal=Journal of Chemical Ecology|date=15 May 2009|volume=35|issue=6|pages=656–663|doi=10.1007/s10886-009-9619-3}}</ref>]]
==Biotic interactions==
=== Perception by flower visitors === Flower visitors such as insects and bats detect floral scent thanks to [[chemoreceptor]]s of variable specificity to a specific VOC. The fixation of a VOC on a chemoreceptor triggers the activation of an antennal glomerulus, further projecting on an olfactory receptor neuron and finally triggering a behavioral response after processing of the information (see also [[Olfaction]], [[Insect olfaction]]). The simultaneous perception of various VOCs may cause the activation of several glomeruli, but the output signal may not be additive due to synergistic or antagonistic mechanisms linked with inter-neuronal activity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cunningham|first=J. P.|date=2012-02-01|title=Can mechanism help explain insect host choice?|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1420-9101.2011.02435.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology|language=en|volume=25|issue=2|pages=244–251|doi=10.1111/j.1420-9101.2011.02435.x|issn=1420-9101|pmid=22225990}}</ref> Therefore, the perception of a VOC within a floral blend may trigger a different behavioral response than when perceived isolated. Similarly, the output signal is not proportional to the amount of VOCs, with some VOCs in low amount in the floral blend having major effects on pollinator behavior. A good characterization of floral scent, both qualitative and quantitative, is necessary to understand and potentially predict flower visitors' behaviour.
Flower visitors use floral scent to detect, recognize and locate their host species, and even to discriminate among flowers of the same plant.<ref name="Dudareva_etal_2006" /> This is made possible by the high specificity of floral scent, where both the diversity of VOCs and their relative amount may characterize the flowering species, an individual plant, a flower of the individual plant, and the distance of the plume from the source.
To make the best use of this specific information, flower visitors rely on long-term and short-term memory that allow them to efficiently choose their flower.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chittka|first=Lars|last2=Thomson|first2=James D.|last3=Waser|first3=Nickolas M.|title=Flower Constancy, Insect Psychology, and Plant Evolution|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s001140050636|journal=Naturwissenschaften|language=en|volume=86|issue=8|pages=361–377|doi=10.1007/s001140050636|issn=0028-1042}}</ref> They learn to associate the floral scent of a plant to a reward such as [[nectar]] and [[pollen]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Giurfa|first=Martin|date=2007-07-17|title=Behavioral and neural analysis of associative learning in the honeybee: a taste from the magic well|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00359-007-0235-9|journal=Journal of Comparative Physiology A|language=en|volume=193|issue=8|pages=801–824|doi=10.1007/s00359-007-0235-9|issn=0340-7594}}</ref> and have different behavioral responses to known scents versus unknown ones.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Junker|first=Robert R.|last2=Höcherl|first2=Nicole|last3=Blüthgen|first3=Nico|date=2010-07-01|title=Responses to olfactory signals reflect network structure of flower-visitor interactions|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2656.2010.01698.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Animal Ecology|language=en|volume=79|issue=4|pages=818–823|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2656.2010.01698.x|issn=1365-2656}}</ref> They are also able to react similarly to slightly different odor blends.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guerrieri|first=Fernando|last2=Schubert|first2=Marco|last3=Sandoz|first3=Jean-Christophe|last4=Giurfa|first4=Martin|date=2005-02-22|title=Perceptual and Neural Olfactory Similarity in Honeybees|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.0030060|journal=PLOS Biol|volume=3|issue=4|pages=e60|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.0030060|issn=1545-7885|pmc=1043859|pmid=15736975}}</ref>
===Mediated biotic interactions=== [[File:Pollinator Amajus.jpg|thumb|300px|Pollinators use both floral scent and floral colour to locate flowers of ''Antirrhinum majus spp. striatum''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jaworski|first1=Coline C.|last2=Andalo|first2=Christophe|last3=Raynaud|first3=Christine|last4=Simon|first4=Valérie|last5=Thébaud|first5=Christophe|last6=Chave|first6=Jérôme|last7=Huang|first7=Shuang-Quan|title=The Influence of Prior Learning Experience on Pollinator Choice: An Experiment Using Bumblebees on Two Wild Floral Types of Antirrhinum majus|journal=PLOS ONE|date=11 August 2015|volume=10|issue=8|pages=e0130225|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0130225|pmid=26263186|pmc=4532467}}</ref>]]A major function of floral scent is to attract [[pollinator]]s, and hence to ensure reproduction of animal-pollinated plants.
Some families of VOCs presented in floral scent have likely evolved as herbivore repellents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schiestl|first=Florian P.|date=2010-05-01|title=The evolution of floral scent and insect chemical communication|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1461-0248.2010.01451.x/abstract|journal=Ecology Letters|language=en|volume=13|issue=5|pages=643–656|doi=10.1111/j.1461-0248.2010.01451.x|issn=1461-0248}}</ref> However, these [[Plant defense against herbivory|plant defenses]] are also used by herbivores themselves to locate a plant resource, similarly to pollinators attracted by floral scent.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Theis|first=Nina|last2=Adler|first2=Lynn S.|date=2012-02-01|title=Advertising to the enemy: enhanced floral fragrance increases beetle attraction and reduces plant reproduction|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1890/11-0825.1/abstract|journal=Ecology|language=en|volume=93|issue=2|pages=430–435|doi=10.1890/11-0825.1|issn=1939-9170}}</ref> Therefore, this [[phenotypic trait]] is subject to antagonistic [[selection pressures]] (positive selection by pollinators and negative selection by herbivores), leading to contrasting [[Evolution|evolutionary patterns]].
=== Plant-plant communications === Floral scents are the only types of volatile cues that can be used to inform other plants about the mating environment. Plants that sense floral scents emitted by other plants can adapt their floral phenotypic traits that affect pollination and mating.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Caruso|first=Christina M.|last2=Parachnowitsch|first2=Amy L.|title=Do Plants Eavesdrop on Floral Scent Signals?|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tplants.2015.09.001|journal=Trends in Plant Science|volume=21|issue=1|pages=9–15|doi=10.1016/j.tplants.2015.09.001}}</ref> For instance, in sexually deceptive orchids, floral scents emitted after pollination reduce attractiveness of the flower to pollinators, which acts as a signal to pollinators to visit unpollinated flowers within an inflorescence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schiestl|first=Florian P.|last2=Ayasse|first2=Manfred|date=2001-02-01|title=Post-pollination emission of a repellent compound in a sexually deceptive orchid: a new mechanism for maximising reproductive success?|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s004420000552|journal=Oecologia|language=en|volume=126|issue=4|pages=531–534|doi=10.1007/s004420000552|issn=0029-8549}}</ref>
==Synthesis of floral VOCs== Most floral VOCs belong to three main chemical classes.<ref name="Piechulla&Effmert_2006"/><ref name="Dudareva_etal_2006">{{cite journal|last1=Dudareva|first1=Natalia|last2=Negre|first2=Florence|last3=Nagegowda|first3=Dinesh A.|last4=Orlova|first4=Irina|title=Plant Volatiles: Recent Advances and Future Perspectives|journal=Critical Reviews in Plant Sciences|date=October 2006|volume=25|issue=5|pages=417–440|doi=10.1080/07352680600899973}}</ref> VOCs in the same chemical class are synthesized from a shared precursor, but the biochemical pathway is specific for each VOC and often varies from a plant species to the other.
[[Terpenoid]]s (or isoprenoids) are derived from [[isoprene]] and synthesized via the [[mevalonate pathway]] or the erythrol phosphate pathway. They represent the majority of floral VOCs, and are often the most abundant compounds in floral scent blends.<ref name="Gershenzon&Dudareva_2007">{{cite journal|last1=Gershenzon|first1=Jonathan|last2=Dudareva|first2=Natalia|title=The function of terpene natural products in the natural world|journal=Nature Chemical Biology|date=18 June 2007|volume=3|issue=7|pages=408–414|doi=10.1038/nchembio.2007.5}}</ref>
The second chemical class is composed of the fatty acid derivatives, synthesized from [[acetyl-CoA]], of which most of them are also known as [[green leaf volatiles]], because there are also emitted by vegetative parts (ie leaves and stems) of plants, and in sometimes higher abundance than from floral tissue.
The third chemical class is composed of benzenoids/[[phenylpropanoid]]s, also known as [[Aromaticity|aromatic compounds]], they are synthesized from [[phenylalanine]].
==Regulation of emissions== Floral scent emissions of most flowering plants vary predictably throughout the day, following a [[circadian rhythm]]. This variation is controlled by light intensity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harmer|first=Stacey L.|last2=Hogenesch|first2=John B.|last3=Straume|first3=Marty|last4=Chang|first4=Hur-Song|last5=Han|first5=Bin|last6=Zhu|first6=Tong|last7=Wang|first7=Xun|last8=Kreps|first8=Joel A.|last9=Kay|first9=Steve A.|date=2000-12-15|title=Orchestrated Transcription of Key Pathways in Arabidopsis by the Circadian Clock|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/290/5499/2110|journal=Science|language=en|volume=290|issue=5499|pages=2110–2113|doi=10.1126/science.290.5499.2110|issn=0036-8075|pmid=11118138}}</ref> Maximal emissions coincide with peaks of highest activity of visiting pollinators. For instance, [[Antirrhinum|snapdragon]] flowers, mostly pollinated by bees, have highest emissions at noon, whereas nocturnally-visited [[Nicotiana|tobacco plants]] have highest emissions at night.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kolosova|first=Natalia|last2=Gorenstein|first2=Nina|last3=Kish|first3=Christine M.|last4=Dudareva|first4=Natalia|date=2001-10-01|title=Regulation of Circadian Methyl Benzoate Emission in Diurnally and Nocturnally Emitting Plants|url=http://www.plantcell.org/content/13/10/2333|journal=The Plant Cell|language=en|volume=13|issue=10|pages=2333–2347|doi=10.1105/tpc.010162|issn=1532-298X|pmc=139162|pmid=11595805}}</ref>
Floral scent emissions also vary along floral development, with highest emissions at anthesis,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dudareva|first=Natalia|last2=Murfitt|first2=Lisa M.|last3=Mann|first3=Craig J.|last4=Gorenstein|first4=Nina|last5=Kolosova|first5=Natalia|last6=Kish|first6=Christine M.|last7=Bonham|first7=Connie|last8=Wood|first8=Karl|date=2000-06-01|title=Developmental Regulation of Methyl Benzoate Biosynthesis and Emission in Snapdragon Flowers|url=http://www.plantcell.org/content/12/6/949|journal=The Plant Cell|language=en|volume=12|issue=6|pages=949–961|doi=10.1105/tpc.12.6.949|issn=1532-298X|pmid=10852939|pmc=149095}}</ref> i.e. when the flower is fecund, and reduced emissions after pollination, probably due to mechanisms linked with fecundation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Negre|first=Florence|last2=Kish|first2=Christine M.|last3=Boatright|first3=Jennifer|last4=Underwood|first4=Beverly|last5=Shibuya|first5=Kenichi|last6=Wagner|first6=Conrad|last7=Clark|first7=David G.|last8=Dudareva|first8=Natalia|date=2003-12-01|title=Regulation of Methylbenzoate Emission after Pollination in Snapdragon and Petunia Flowers|url=http://www.plantcell.org/content/15/12/2992|journal=The Plant Cell|language=en|volume=15|issue=12|pages=2992–3006|doi=10.1105/tpc.016766|issn=1532-298X|pmc=282847|pmid=14630969}}</ref> In tropical orchids, floral scent emission is terminated immediately following pollination, primarily to reduce expenditure of energy on fragrance production.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0065-2296(08)60091-9|title=Aspects of the Physiology of Orchids|last=Arditti|first=Joseph|pages=421–655|doi=10.1016/s0065-2296(08)60091-9}}</ref> In petunia flowers, ethylene is released to stop synthesis of benzenoid floral volatiles after successful pollination.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schuurink|first=Robert C.|last2=Haring|first2=Michel A.|last3=Clark|first3=David G.|date=|title=Regulation of volatile benzenoid biosynthesis in petunia flowers|journal=Trends in Plant Science|language=en|volume=11|issue=1|pages=20–25|doi=10.1016/j.tplants.2005.09.009|via=}}</ref>
Abiotic factors, such as temperature, atmospheric CO2 concentration, hydric stress and soil nutrient status also impact the regulation of floral scent.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-04670-4_10|title=Plant Developmental Biology - Biotechnological Perspectives|last=Piechulla|first=B.|last2=Effmert|first2=U.|date=2010-01-01|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=9783642046698|editor-last=Pua|editor-first=Eng Chong|pages=189–205|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-642-04670-4_10|editor-last2=Davey|editor-first2=Michael R.}}</ref> For instance, increased temperatures in the environment can increase emission of VOCs in flowers, potentially altering communication between plants and pollinators.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Farré-Armengol|first=Gerard|last2=Filella|first2=Iolanda|last3=Llusià|first3=Joan|last4=Niinemets|first4=Ülo|last5=Peñuelas|first5=Josep|date=|title=Changes in floral bouquets from compound-specific responses to increasing temperatures|journal=Global Change Biology|language=en|volume=20|issue=12|pages=3660–3669|doi=10.1111/gcb.12628|via=}}</ref>
Finally, biotic interactions may affect floral scent. Plant leaves attacked by herbivores emit new VOCs in response to the attack, the so-called herbivore-induced plant volatiles (HIPVs).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Arimura|first=Gen-ichiro|last2=Matsui|first2=Kenji|last3=Takabayashi|first3=Junji|date=2009-05-01|title=Chemical and Molecular Ecology of Herbivore-Induced Plant Volatiles: Proximate Factors and Their Ultimate Functions|url=http://pcp.oxfordjournals.org/content/50/5/911|journal=Plant and Cell Physiology|language=en|volume=50|issue=5|pages=911–923|doi=10.1093/pcp/pcp030|issn=0032-0781|pmid=19246460}}</ref> Similarly, damaged flowers have a modified floral scent compared to undamaged ones. Micro-organisms present in nectar may alter floral scent emissions as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peñuelas|first=Josep|last2=Farré-Armengol|first2=Gerard|last3=Llusia|first3=Joan|last4=Gargallo-Garriga|first4=Albert|last5=Rico|first5=Laura|last6=Sardans|first6=Jordi|last7=Terradas|first7=Jaume|last8=Filella|first8=Iolanda|date=2014-10-22|title=Removal of floral microbiota reduces floral terpene emissions|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep06727|journal=Scientific Reports|language=en|volume=4|doi=10.1038/srep06727|issn=2045-2322|pmc=4205883|pmid=25335793|pages=6727}}</ref>
==Measurement== Measuring floral scent both qualitatively (identification of VOCs) and quantitatively (absolute and/or relative emission of VOCs) requires the use of [[analytical chemistry]] techniques. It requires to collect floral VOCs, and then to analyze them.
=== VOCs sampling === Most used methods rely on adsorbing floral VOCs on an adsorbent material such as [[Solid phase extraction#Solid-phase microextraction|SPME fibers]] or [[Solid phase extraction#Cartridges|cartridges]] by pumping air sampled around inflorescences through the adsorbent material.
It is also possible to extract chemicals stocked in petals by immersing them into a [[solvent]], and then analyze the liquid residue. This is more adapted to the study of heavier organic compounds, and/or VOCs that are stored in floral tissue before being emitted in air.
=== Sample analysis ===
==== Desorption ==== {{Main article|Desorption}} * thermodesorption: the adsorbent material is flash-heated so that all adsorbed VOCs are carried away from the adsorbent and injected into the separation system. This is how work injectors in [[gas chromatography]] machines, which literally volatilize introduced samples. For VOCs adsorbed on bigger amount of adsorbent material such as [[Solid phase extraction#Cartridges|cartridges]], thermodesorption may require the use of a specific machine, a thermodesorber, connected to the separation system. * desorption by [[solvent]]: VOCs adsorbed on the adsorbent material are carried away by a small quantity of solvent which is then volatilized in injected in the separation system. Most commonly used solvents are very volatile molecules, such as [[methanol]], so as to avoid co-elution with slightly heavier VOCs
==== Separation ==== [[Gas chromatography]] (GC) is ideal to separate volatilized VOCs due to their low molecular weight. VOCs are carried by a gas vector (helium) through a chromatographic column (the solid phase) on which they have different affinities, which allows to separate them.
[[Liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry|Liquid chromatography]] may be used for liquid extractions of floral tissue.
==== Detection and identification ==== Separation systems are coupled with a [[Gas chromatography#Detectors|detector]], that allows the detection and identification of VOCs based on their molecular weight and chemical properties. The most used system for the analysis of floral scent samples is [[Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry|GC-MS]] (gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry).
==== Quantification ==== [[Gas chromatography#Quantitative analysis|Quantification]] of VOCs is based on the peak area measured on the chromatogram and compared to the peak area of a chemical standard:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tholl|first=Dorothea|last2=Boland|first2=Wilhelm|last3=Hansel|first3=Armin|last4=Loreto|first4=Francesco|last5=Röse|first5=Ursula S.R.|last6=Schnitzler|first6=Jörg-Peter|date=2006-02-01|title=Practical approaches to plant volatile analysis|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-313X.2005.02612.x/abstract|journal=The Plant Journal|language=en|volume=45|issue=4|pages=540–560|doi=10.1111/j.1365-313X.2005.02612.x|issn=1365-313X}}</ref> * internal calibration: a known quantity of a specific chemical standard is injected together with the VOCs, the measured area on the chromatogram is proportional to the injected quantity. Because the chemical properties of VOCs alter their affinity to the solid phase (the chromatographic column) and subsequently the peak area on the chromatogram, it is best to use several standards that best reflect the chemical diversity of the floral scent sample. This method allows a more robust comparison among samples. * external calibration: calibration curves (quantity vs. peak area) are established independently by the injection of a range of quantities of chemical standard. This method is best when the relative and absolute amount of VOCs in floral scent samples varies from sample to sample and from VOC to VOC and when the chemical diversity of VOCs in the sample is high. However, it is more time consuming and may be source of errors (e.g. matrix effects due to solvent or very abundant VOCs compared to trace VOCs<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Ki-Hyun|last2=Kim|first2=Yong-Hyun|last3=Brown|first3=Richard J. C.|date=2013-08-02|title=Conditions for the optimal analysis of volatile organic compounds in air with sorbent tube sampling and liquid standard calibration: demonstration of solvent effect|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00216-013-7263-9|journal=Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry|language=en|volume=405|issue=26|pages=8397–8408|doi=10.1007/s00216-013-7263-9|issn=1618-2642}}</ref>).
=== Specificity of floral scent analysis === Floral scent is often composed of hundreds of VOCs, in very variable proportions. The method used is a tradeoff between accurately detecting quantifying minor compounds and avoiding detector saturation by major compounds. For most analysis methods routinely used, the detection threshold of many VOCs is still higher than the perception threshold of insects,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Macel|first=Mirka|last2=Van DAM|first2=Nicole M.|last3=Keurentjes|first3=Joost J. B.|date=2010-07-01|title=Metabolomics: the chemistry between ecology and genetics|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1755-0998.2010.02854.x/abstract|journal=Molecular Ecology Resources|language=en|volume=10|issue=4|pages=583–593|doi=10.1111/j.1755-0998.2010.02854.x|issn=1755-0998}}</ref> which reduces our capacity to understand plant-insect interactions mediated by floral scent.
Further, the chemical diversity in floral scent samples is challenging. The time of analysis is proportional to the range in molecular weight of VOCs present in the sample, hence a high diversity will increase analysis time. Floral scent may also be composed of very similar molecules, such as [[isomer]]s and especially [[enantiomer]]s, which tend to co-elute and then to be very hardly separated. Unambiguously detecting and quantifying them is of importance though, as enantiomers may trigger very different responses in pollinators.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Parachnowitsch|first=Amy|last2=Burdon|first2=Rosalie C. F.|last3=Raguso|first3=Robert A.|last4=Kessler|first4=André|date=2013-01-01|title=Natural selection on floral volatile production in Penstemon digitalis: Highlighting the role of linalool|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.4161/psb.22704|journal=Plant Signaling & Behavior|volume=8|issue=1|pages=e22704|doi=10.4161/psb.22704|pmc=3745574|pmid=23221753}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=August 2011}} {{globalize|us|date=March 2015}} }}
'''Gender-biased diagnosing''' is a controversial<ref>Authors V. Mark Durand, M.V. & Barlow, D.H. (2009) ''Essentials of Abnormal Psychology'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=L7BZTtO5rh8C&lpg=PA436&dq=gender%20biased%20diagnosing&pg=PA436#v=onepage&q=gender%20biased%20diagnosing&f=false p.436.] Cengage Learning. {{ISBN|0-495-59982-4}}. Retrieved November 2011</ref> [[Sociology|sociological]] observation which asserts that [[medical diagnosis|medical]] and psychological diagnosis may be influenced by the [[gender]] of the patient. Several studies have found evidence of [[differential diagnosis]] for patients with similar ailments but of different sexes.
== Medical diagnosis == {{unreferenced section|date=October 2013}} The phenomenon may affect physical diagnosis. Women are more likely to be given a diagnosis of [[Psychosomatic medicine|psychosomatic]] nature for a [[physical ailment]] than men, despite presenting with similar symptoms. Women sometimes have trouble being taken seriously by physicians when suffering from medically unexplained [[illness]], and report difficulty receiving appropriate medical care for their illnesses because doctors repeatedly diagnose their physical complaints as related to [[Mental illness|psychiatric problems]]. Clinical offices that rely on healthcare routines become less distinct due to biased medical knowledge of gender. There is a distinct differentiation between gender and sex in the medical sense. Gender is the societal construction of what femininity and masculinity is, whereas, sex is the biological aspect that defines the dichotomy of female and male. The way of lifestyle and the place in society are often considered when diagnosing patients.<ref>Hamberg, K. (2008). Gender bias in medicine. Women's Health (London, England), 4(3), 237-243.</ref>
According to traditional medical studies, most of these medical studies were done on men thus overlooking many issues that were related to women's health. This topic alone sparked controversy and brought about question to the medical standard of our time. Research that was done on diseases that affected women more were less funded than those diseases that affected men and women equally.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Trechak A | year = 1999 | title = On cultural and gender bias in medical diagnosis | url = | journal = Multicultural Education | volume = 7 | issue = 2| page = 41 }}</ref>
There was an example of gender bias in the psychiatric field as well, Hamburg notes that, "psychiatrists would diagnose women with depression and then, eventually psychiatrists would begin to assume that women were more depressed than men due to the fact that the patients that were examined by the psychiatrists were women and they had similar symptoms. As for the men, they were diagnosed with drug or alcohol problems and they were thrown out of the study."<ref>Hamberg, Katarina. "Gender Bias in Medicine." Women's Health (London, England), 4.3 (2008): 237-243.</ref>
As for the Women's Health Equity Act that was passed in 1993, this Act gave women the chance to participate in medical studies and examine the gender differences.<ref>WOMEN'S HEALTH EQUITY ACT of 1993. Congressional Record Daily Edition. n.p.: 1993.</ref> Before the Women's Health Equity Act was introduced there was no research done on infertility, breast cancer, and ovarian cancer which were essential to women's health.<ref>THE WOMEN'S HEALTH EQUITY ACT of 1991. Congressional Record Daily Edition. n.p.: 1991.</ref>
== Psychological diagnosis == There is a suggestion that assumptions regarding gender specific behavioural characteristics can lead to a diagnostic system which is biased.<ref>Maddux, J.E. & Winstead, B.A. (2005) ''Psychopathology: foundations for a contemporary understanding'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=2SJpF8ucrKgC&lpg=PA77&dq=gender%20biased%20diagnosing&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q=gender%20biased%20diagnosing&f=false p.77.] Routledge. {{ISBN|0-8058-4077-X}} Retrieved November 2011</ref> The issue of gender bias with regard to ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'' (DSM) [[personality disorder]] criteria has been controversial and widely debated. The fourth DSM (4th ed., text revision; DSM–IV–TR; American Psychiatric Association, 2000) makes no explicit statement regarding gender bias among the ten personality disorders (PDs), but it does state that six PDs (antisocial, narcissistic, obsessive-compulsive, paranoid, schizotypal, schizoid) are more frequently found in men. Three others (borderline, histrionic, dependent) are more frequent in women. Avoidant is equally common in men and women.
There are many ways to interpret differential prevalence rates as a function of gender. Some critics have argued that they are an artifact of gender bias. In other words, the PD criteria assume unfairly that stereotypical female characteristics are pathological. The results of this study conclude with no indication of gender-biased criteria in the [[borderline personality disorder|borderline]], [[histrionic personality disorder|histrionic]], and [[dependent personality disorder|dependent]] PDs. This is in contrast with what is predicted by critics of these disorders, who suggest they are biased against women. It is possible, however, that other sources of bias, including assessment and clinical bias, are still at work in relation to these disorders. The results do show that the group means are higher in women than in men, an expected result considering the higher prevalence rate of these disorders for women.<ref>Jane, J. S., Oltmanns, T. F., South, S. C., & Turkheimer, E. (2007) "Gender bias in diagnostic criteria for personality disorders: An item response theory analysis" Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 116(1), 166-175</ref>
The original purpose of the DSM–IV was to provide an accurate classification of [[psychopathology]], not to develop a diagnostic system that will, democratically, diagnose as many men with a personality disorder as women". However, if the criteria are to serve equally as indicators of disorder for both men and women, it will be important to establish that the implications of these criteria for functional impairment are comparable for both sexes. Whereas it is plausible that there are gender-specific expressions of these disorders, DSM–IV criteria that function differentially for men and women can systematically over-pathologize or under-represent mental illness in a particular gender. The present study is limited by the investigation of only four personality disorders and the lack of inclusion of additional diagnoses that have also been controversial in the gender bias debate (such as dependent and histrionic personality disorders), although it offers a clearly articulated methodology for studying this possibility. In addition, it provides an examination of a clinical sample of substantial size and uses functional assessments that cut across multiple functional domains and multiple assessment methods. Our results indicate that BPD criteria showed some evidence of differential functioning between genders on global functioning, although there is little evidence of sex bias within the diagnostic criteria for [[avoidant personality disorder|avoidant]], [[schizotypal personality disorder|schizotypal]], or [[obsessive–compulsive personality disorder]]s. Further investigation and validation across sexes for those disorders would be an important direction of future research.<ref>Boggs, C. D., Morey, L. C., Skodol, A. E., Shea, M. T., Sanislow, C. A., Grilo, C. M., et al. (2009) "Differential impairment as an indicator of sex bias in DSM-IV criteria for four personality disorders" Personality Disorders: Theory, Research, and Treatment, S(1), 61-68.</ref>
Considerable evidence indicates a prominent role for [[psychological trauma|trauma]]-related cognitions in the development and maintenance of [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) symptoms. The present study utilized [[regression analysis]] to examine the unique relationships between various trauma-related cognitions and PTSD symptoms after controlling for gender and measures of general affective distress in a large sample of trauma-exposed college students. In terms of trauma-related cognitions, only negative cognitions about the self were related to PTSD symptom severity. Gender and anxiety symptoms were also related to PTSD symptom severity. Theoretical implications of the results are consistent with previous studies on the relationship between PTSD and negative cognitions, the self, world, and blame subscales of the PTCI were significantly related to PTSD symptoms. The study correlations indicated that increased negative trauma-related cognitions were related to more severe PTSD symptoms. Also consistent with previous reports, correlations also indicated that gender was related to PTSD symptom severity, such that women had more severe PTSD symptoms. PTSD symptom severity was also positively related to depression, anxiety, and stress reactivity.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Moser J. S. |author2=Hajcak G. |author3=Simons R. F. |author4=Foa E. B. | year = 2007 | title = Posttraumatic stress disorder symptoms in trauma-exposed college students: The role of trauma-related cognitions, gender, and negative affect | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0887618507000072 | journal = Journal of Anxiety Disorders | volume = 21 | issue = 8| pages = 1039–1049 | doi=10.1016/j.janxdis.2006.10.009|pmc=2169512 }}</ref>
Distinguishing between borderline personality disorder (BPD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is often challenging, especially when the client has experienced a trauma such as [[childhood sexual abuse]] (CSA), which is strongly linked to both disorders. Although the individual diagnostic criteria for these two disorders do not overlap substantially, patients with either of these disorders can display similar clinical pictures. Both patients with BPD and PTSD may present as aggressive toward self or others, irritable, unable to tolerate emotional extremes, dysphoric, feeling empty or dead, and highly reactive to mild stressors. Despite having similar clinical pictures, PTSD and BPD are regarded differently by many clinicians. Results from a 2009 study concluded that patient gender does not affect diagnosis. This finding is consistent with research suggesting that women are not more likely to be given the BPD diagnosis, all else being equal, though it contradicts other findings from studies that have used similar case vignettes. Nor did the data support an effect of clinician gender or age on diagnosis.<ref>Woodward, H. E., Taft, C. T., Gordon, R. A., & Meis, L. A. (2009) "Clinician bias in the diagnosis of posttraumatic stress disorder and borderline personality disorder" Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy, 1(4), 282-290.</ref>
A 2012 study examined gender-specific associations between trauma cognitions, alcohol cravings and alcohol-related consequences in individuals with dually diagnosed PTSD and [[alcohol dependence]] (AD). Participants had entered a treatment study for concurrent PTSD and AD; baseline information was collected from participants about PTSD-related cognitions in three areas: (a) Negative Cognitions About Self, (b) Negative Cognitions About the World, and (c) Self-Blame. Information was also collected on two aspects of AD: alcohol cravings and consequences of AD. Gender differences were examined while controlling for PTSD severity. The results indicate that Negative Cognitions About Self are significantly related to alcohol cravings in men but not women, and that interpersonal consequences of AD are significantly related to Self-Blame in women but not in men. These findings suggest that for individuals with comorbid PTSD and AD, psychotherapeutic interventions that focus on reducing trauma-related cognitions are likely to reduce alcohol cravings in men and relational problems in women.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Jayawickreme N. |author2=Yasinski C. |author3=Williams M. |author4=Foa E. B. | year = 2012 | title = Gender-specific associations between trauma cognitions, alcohol cravings, and alcohol-related consequences in individuals with comorbid PTSD and alcohol dependence | url = http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/adb/26/1/13.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Psychology of Addictive Behaviors | volume = 26 | issue = 1| pages = 13–19 | doi=10.1037/a0023363|pmc=3213324 }}</ref>

'''Hairy root culture''', also called '''transformed root culture''', is a type of [[plant tissue culture]] that is used to study plant metabolic processes or to produce valuable [[secondary metabolites]] or recombinant proteins, often with plant [[genetic engineering]].<ref name="Sévon and Oksman">{{cite journal |doi=10.1055/s-2002-34924 |author=Sévon and Oksman |title=Agrobacterium rhizogenes-mediated transformation: root cultures as a source of alkaloids. |journal=Planta Med. |volume=68 |issue=10 |pages=859–68 |date=October 2002 |url=https://www.thieme-connect.com/DOI/DOI?10.1055/s-2002-34924}}</ref>
A naturally occurring soil bacterium ''[[Agrobacterium rhizogenes]]'' that contains root-inducing plasmids (also called Ri plasmids) can infect plant roots and cause them to produce a food source for the bacterium, [[opines]], and to grow abnormally.<ref name=Shanks>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0958-1669(99)80026-3 |vauthors=Shanks JV, Morgan J |title=Plant 'hairy root' culture |journal=Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. |volume=10 |issue=2 |pages=151–5 |date=April 1999 |pmid=10209145 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0958-1669(99)80026-3}}</ref> The abnormal roots are particularly easy to culture in artificial media because hormones are not needed in contrast to adventitious roots,<ref name=Shanks/> and they are [[Neoplasm|neoplastic]], with indefinite growth. The neoplastic roots produced by ''A. rhizogenes'' infection have a high growth rate (compared to untransformed [[Root#Specialized roots|adventitious roots]]), as well as genetic and biochemical stability.
Currently the main constraint for commercial utilization of hairy root culture is the development and up-scaling of appropriate ([[bioreactors]]) vessels for the delicate and sensitive hairy roots.<ref name=Shanks/><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Guillon S, Tremouillaux-Guiller J, Pati PK, Rideau M, Gantet P |year=2006|title=Hairy root research: recent scenario and exciting prospects|journal=Curr Opin Plant Biol|volume=9|pages=341–346|pmid=16616871|doi=10.1016/j.pbi.2006.03.008}}</ref>
Some of the applied research on utilization of hairy root cultures has been and is conducted at VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland Ltd.<ref name="Häkkinen">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/jxb/eri253 |author1=Häkkinen S |title=Enhanced secretion of tropane alkaloids in Nicotiana tabacum hairy roots expressing heterologous hyoscyamine-6beta-hydroxylase. |journal=J. Exp. Bot. |volume=56 |issue=420 |pages=2611–8 |date=August 2005 |url=http://jxb.oxfordjournals.org/content/56/420/2611.long|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Ritala>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jbiotec.2014.01.031 |author1=Ritala A |title=Evaluation of tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum L. cv. Petit Havana SR1) hairy roots for the production of geraniol, the first committed step in terpenoid indole alkaloid pathway. |journal=J. Biotechnol. |volume=176 |date=April 2014 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168165614000558|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Other labs working on hairy roots are the phytotechnology lab of Amiens University and the Arkansas Biosciences Institute.
== Metabolic studies == Hairy root cultures can be used for [[phytoremediation]], and are particularly valuable for studies of the metabolic processes involved in phytoremediation.<ref name=Shanks/>
Further applications include detailed studies of fundamental molecular, genetic and biochemical aspects of genetic transformation and of hairy root induction.<ref name=Georgiev>{{cite book |editor=R Arora|author1=Georgiev M |author2=Ludwig-Müller J |author3=Bley Th |chapter=Hairy root culture: Copying Nature in New Bioprocesses (chapter 10)|title=Medicinal Plant Biotechnology|year=2010|publisher= The Institute of Nuclear Medicine and Applied Sciences|location=Delhi|isbn=978-1-84593-678-5}}</ref>
== Genetically transformed cultures == The Ri plasmids can be [[Genetic engineering|engineered]] to also contain [[Transfer DNA|T-DNA]], used for genetic transformation (biotransformation) of the plant cells. The resulting genetically transformed root cultures can produce high levels of secondary metabolites, comparable or even higher than those of intact plants.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Georgiev M |author2=Pavlov A |author3=Bley Th |title=Hairy root type plant in vitro systems as sources of bioactive substances|journal=Appl. Microbiol. Biotechnol. |volume=74 |issue=6 |pages=1175–1185 |year=2007 |pmid=17294182 |doi=10.1007/s00253-007-0856-5|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/a6p70811x6vpnj86/}}</ref>
== Use in plant propagation == Hairy root culture can also be used for regeneration of whole plants and for production of [[Plant embryogenesis|artificial seeds]].<ref name=Georgiev/> {{Expand section|date= August 2010}}
== See also == * Crown gall, a plant disease with similar uses caused by a related bacterium, ''[[Agrobacterium tumefaciens]]''

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{ course assignment | course = Education Program:University of Michigan/Social Work Practice with Community and Social Systems (Winter 2014) | term = 2013 Q3 }} {{Criminology and penology}} '''Incarceration prevention''' refers to a variety of methods aimed at reducing prison populations and costs while fostering enhanced social structures. Due to the nature of [[incarceration in the United States]] today caused by issues leading to increased incarceration rates, there are methods aimed at preventing the incarceration of at-risk populations.
== Prison population and cost to society==
{{See also|United States incarceration rate}}
Between 1998 and 2010, prison populations in the United States rose dramatically. This resulted in overcrowded facilities; increased expense to taxpayers; and potential loss of public funding for other community safety activities.<ref>{{cite book|title=Examining growth in the federal prison population, 1998 to 2010|url=http://www.urban.org/UploadedPDF/412720-Examining-Growth-in-the-Federal-Prison-Population.pdf|year=2012|publisher=Urban Institute|location=Washington, D.C.|author=Kamala Kane|author2=Barbara Parthasarathy|accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> Between 1982 and 2007, corrections expenditures increased by over 250 percent and in 2007 expenditure was over $74 billion.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kyckelhahn|first=Tracey|title=Justice Expenditures and Employment, FY 1982-2007|date=December 2011|publisher=Bureau of Justice Statistics|url=http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/jee8207st.pdf}}</ref> In 2010, the number of youths in detention facilities was 61,423.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Center for Juvenile Justice|url=http://www.ojjdp.gov/ojstatbb/ezacjrp/asp/selection.asp|publisher=Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP), Office of Justice Programs, U.S. Department of Justice.|accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> By the end of 2012, approximately 2,228,400 individuals were incarcerated in jails and prisons, about 4,781,300 individuals were under some form of community supervision (such as probation or parole), and a total of approximately 6,937,600 individuals were under some form of correctional supervision (1 in 35 adults).<ref name="bjs">{{cite web|title = Correctional Populations in the United States, 2012|url = http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/cpus12.pdf|work = Office of Justice Programs Bureau of Justice Statistics Bulletin|publisher = U.S. Department of Justice|accessdate = 24 February 2014|author = Lauren Glaze|author2 = Erinn Herberman}}</ref> The average cost of the incarceration of an individual in 2012 was approximately $31,286 per year with a range of $14,603 to $60,076.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Price of Prisons: What Incarceration Costs Taxpayers|date=January 2012|publisher=The VERA Institute of Justice Center on Sentencing and Corrections|location=New York|url=http://www.vera.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/Price_of_Prisons_updated_version_072512.pdf|author=Christian Henrichson|author2=Ruth Delaney|accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Economic Interest Convergence in Downsizing Imprisonment|ssrn = 2608698|publisher = Social Science Research Network|date = 2014-01-01|location = Rochester, NY|last = SpearIt}}</ref>
As of October 2015, the United States has the second highest incarceration rate in the world with 698 per 100,000 population.<ref name=Walmsley2015>{{cite web|last1=Walmsley|first1=Roy|title=World Prison Population List (Eleventh Edition)|url=http://www.prisonstudies.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/world_prison_population_list_11th_edition_0.pdf|website=World Prison Brief|publisher=Institute For Criminal Policy Research|accessdate=25 November 2017|date=2015}}</ref> Compared to other locations, 55% of countries and territories have prison rates lower than 155 per 100,000 population.<ref name=Walmsley2015 /> The average cost of incarceration rose to $31,977.65 in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Federal Bureau of Prisons|first1=Justice Department|title=Annual Determination of Average Cost of Incarceration|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/07/19/2016-17040/annual-determination-of-average-cost-of-incarceration|website=Federal Register|accessdate=25 November 2017|date=2016}}</ref>
== Factors contributing to incarceration rates==
=== Substance use disorder prevention or treatment ===
Between 1980 and 2005, the number of inmates incarcerated for drug-related crimes increased by 1,000 percent.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stemen|first=Don|title=Reconsidering Incarceration: New Directions for Reducing Crime|date=January 2007|publisher=VERA Institute of Justice Center on Sentencing and Corrections|pages=8|url=http://www.vera.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/veraincarc_vFW2.pdf}}</ref> In 2012, sixty-five percent of inmates reported a substance addiction or dependence issue.<ref name = casa>{{cite book|title=Shoveling Up II: The Impact of Substance Abuse on Federal, State and Local Budgets|date=May 2009|publisher=The National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University|location=New York, NY|url=http://www.casacolumbia.org/modal_forms/nojs/webform/161}}</ref> Seventy-eight percent of violent crimes and eighty-three percent of property crimes involved drugs.<ref name=casa /> A greater amount of money is spent on incarceration than on prevention and treatment, despite research showing that treating drug addictions is more cost-effective than incarceration.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wachendorfer|first=Allan|title=Casualties of the Drug War|journal=Senior Honors Thesis|year=2013|issue=Paper 361|url=http://commons.emich.edu/honors/361}}</ref> According to the [[National Institute on Drug Abuse]], a full year of drug treatment costs approximately $4,700 compared to over $30,000 for a year of imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Is drug addiction treatment worth its cost?|url=http://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/principles-drug-addiction-treatment-research-based-guide-third-edition/frequently-asked-questions/drug-addiction-treatment-worth-its-cost|publisher=National Institute on Drug Abuse}}</ref>
=== Mental health access/treatment ===
According to statistics produced by the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] in September 2006, over 45% of federal prisoners, 56% of state prisoners, and 64% of jail inmates are [[Mentally ill prisoners in the United States|diagnosed with mental health problems]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Bureau of Justice Statistics Special Report: Mental Health Problems of Prison and Jail Inmates|date=September 2006|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice Office of Justice Programs|url=http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/mhppji.pdf|author=Doris James|author2=Lauren Glaze|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> This suggests a direct correlation between a decrease in mental health services and facilities and an increase in mental health diagnoses in the prison system. A decrease in mental health funding has taken place on both the state and federal level, especially in changes in block grant funding as part of the Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1981. The statewide support for mental health services has also seen significant cuts and has barely accounted for annual inflation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Funding for Mental Health Services and Programs|url=//www.bazelon.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=GzmAbAweikQ%3D&tabid=436|publisher=Judge David L. Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law}}</ref> The overall shift from institution-based care to a community-based care model was one that many mental health advocates welcomed; however, the funding appropriated to support such programs was much less than initial estimates and has had a significant impact on the ability of the community care based model to be successful in providing adequate mental health treatment to those in need.<ref>NAMI - State Mental Health Cuts : A National Crisis http://www.nami.org/ContentManagement/ContentDisplay.cfm?ContentFileID=126233</ref>
=== Education ===
{{See also|School-to-prison pipeline}}
68% of state prison inmates did not receive a high school diploma.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bureau of Justice Statistics Special Report: Education and Correctional Populations|date=January 2003|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice Office of Justice Programs|url=http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/ecp.pdf}}</ref> Research indicates that schooling significantly reduces criminal activity. A significant portion of the effect of education on crime can be attributed to an increase in wages associated with schooling, suggesting that an increased level of education funding will result in decreased criminal activity.<ref>{{cite book|title=The E®ect of Education on Crime: Evidence from Prison Inmates, Arrests, and Self-Reports|date=October 2003|url=http://emlab.berkeley.edu/~moretti/lm46.pdf|author=Lance Lochner|author2=Enrico Moretti|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
[[File:IncarcerationRates2010.png|thumb|upright=2|{{Unordered list|Counts based on prisoners with a sentence of more than 1 year. All estimates include persons under age 18. |"Total" includes American Indians, Alaska Natives, Asians, Native Hawaiians, other Pacific Islanders, and persons identifying as two or more races. |"Black" excludes persons of Hispanic or Latino origin.}}]]
=== Factors involving race ===
{{see also|Race and the War on Drugs|Stop-and-frisk in New York City|Arizona SB 1070|Race and crime in the United States}}
There are many factors that have direct connections with the rises in the incarcerated population, many of which relate to structural and societal biases that exist in America today. As it relates directly to race, the practice of racial profiling regards policies and personal biases that target minority racial groups and contribute to a greater proportion of minorities being incarcerated compared to the general population. Currently, over sixty percent of inmates in the United States are people of color.<ref>http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/race/news/2012/03/13/11351/the-top-10-most-startling-facts-about-people-of-color-and-criminal-justice-in-the-united-states/</ref> These practices have existed in the American Criminal Justice system for decades and although may have gained attention in recent years, still find ways to increase the likelihood of certain demographic groups receiving negative attention from the likes of law enforcement.
=== The war on drugs and longer prison sentences ===
Beginning in the Nixon administration, the war on drugs resulted in stricter drug laws including longer prison sentences for drug use and possession.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Travis|first1=Jeremy|last2=Western|first2=Bruce|last3=Redburn|first3=F. Stevens|title=The Growth of Incarceration in the United States: Exploring Causes and Consequences|date=2014|publisher=The National Academic Press|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=118–121|url=https://academicworks.cuny.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1026&context=jj_pubs|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref> The Bureau of Justice Statistics reports that the drug offender population in federal prisons rose by 63% from 1998 to 2012 and they accounted for 52% of federal prisoners by 2012.<ref name=Taxy2015>{{cite web|last1=Taxy|first1=Sam|last2=Samuels|first2=Julie|last3=Adams|first3=William|title=Drug Offenders in Federal Prison: Estimates of Characteristics Based on Linked Data|url=https://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/dofp12.pdf|website=Bureau of Justice Statistics|accessdate=27 November 2017|date=2015}}</ref> 35% of these drug offenders were not reoffenders or had minimal criminal backgrounds.<ref name=Taxy2015 />
In relation, mandatory minimum penalties have contributed to mass incarceration. The United States Sentencing Commission found that in 2016, 67.3% of offenders charged of a crime with a mandatory minimum penalty were convicted of a drug offense.<ref name=USSC2017>{{cite web|last1=United States Sentencing Commission|title=An Overview of Mandatory Minimum Penalties in the Federal Criminal Justice System|url=https://www.ussc.gov/sites/default/files/pdf/research-and-publications/research-publications/2017/20170711_Mand-Min.pdf|accessdate=27 November 2017|date=2017}}</ref> The Commission also found that in 2016, the average sentence length was 110 months in prison compared to 28 months for those charged of a crime with no mandatory minimum penalty.<ref name=USSC2017 />
== Incarceration prevention ==
Incarceration prevention refers to a variety of methods aimed at reducing prison populations and costs while fostering enhanced social structures for the improvement of society. Incarceration prevention can take place in any of three stages: Primary Prevention, Diversion, or Recidivism Prevention.
===Prevention===
Primary prevention is an attempt to reduce the risk of behaviors that potentially lead to incarceration. The initial stage in this model includes looking at system wide or systemic approaches that ensure people have consistent social and structural interactions.
{| class="wikitable" align = right style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+A 1% Decrease in the Unemployment Rate Relates to the Following Decreases in the Crime Rate<ref>{{cite web|title=Effective Investments in Public Safety Unemployment, Wages, and the Crime Rate|url=http://www.justicepolicy.org/uploads/justicepolicy/documents/07-02_fac_employmentwages_ac-ps.pdf|publisher=Justice Policy Institute|accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref> |- ! width="140" |Type of Crime !! Percentage Decrease in Crime |- | Property Crime || style="text-align: center;"| 1.6-2.4% |- | Violent Crime || style="text-align: center;"| .5% |- | Burglary || style="text-align: center;"| 2% |- | Larceny || style="text-align: center;"| 1.5% |- | Auto Theft || style="text-align: center;"| 1% |}
==== Safety nets ====
Studies suggest that crime and violence are likely to be a byproduct of issues including economic inequality and poverty.<ref name=worldbank>{{cite book|last=Bourguignon|first=F.|title=Facets of globalization international and local dimensions of development|year=2001|publisher=The World Bank|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-8213-4742-X|url=https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/14014|accessdate=25 February 2014|format=print|chapter=10}}</ref> Economic theory shows how property crime and violent crimes may partly be consequences of excessive inequality and poverty.<ref name=worldbank /> Not only do crime rates increase with inequality, but propensity to commit crimes also increases with greater income inequality or poverty.<ref name=worldbank /> It follows that programs which elevate families out of poverty decrease behaviors associated with crime. National data indicates that a 10% increase in real wages lowers the crime index by 13%.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stemen|first=Don|title=New Directions for Reducing Crime|journal=Federal Sentencing Reporter|date=April 2007|volume=19|issue=4|pages=221–233|doi=10.1525/fsr.2007.19.4.221|jstor=10.1525/fsr.2007.19.4.221}}</ref>
==== Youth justice ====
{{See also|School-to-prison pipeline}}
Often, primary prevention can be viewed in the context of a school or vocational program in which there is a system of disciplinary action and reactions to behavioral issues. The goal is to institute preventive measures and different methods of support (i.e., restorative justice, restorative circles, proactive circles, and peer mediation) that encourage students/youth to meet the behavioral and academic standards set before them, without instituting harsh punitive measures that disengage students from educational and social resources provided within a school environment.{{Citation needed|date=September 2014}}
=== Diversion ===
Diversion is an attempt to circumvent incarceration and correct problem behaviors after an offense have been committed through alternatives to incarceration. This includes identifying those "most at risk" and setting in place additional supportive measures and strategies to provide opportunities for success.
In a school setting, this most often takes place after a young person has had multiple behavioral incidences within a short period of time and is at risk for more serious punitive measures. Steps for intervention may include (but are not limited to): additional counseling and support services, conflict resolution measures, peer-to-peer resolution groups, and engagement with community partners to provide additional services. The goal is to provide opportunities and support for those who show persistent behavioral issues, as they are most at-risk for future incarceration and/or legal trouble.<ref>EDJ Model: Secondary http://www.edjj.org/prevention/LevelsPrevention.html</ref>
==== Deferred sentencing and jail diversion ====
Including but not limited to:
*[[Alternative sentencing|Community Service]]: Community sentence or alternative sentencing or non-custodial sentence is a collective name in criminal justice for all the different ways, in which courts can punish someone convicted of committing an offense in ways other than prison terms. *[[Drug courts in the United States|Drug courts]]: Drug courts operate under a model that combines intensive judicial supervision, mandatory drug testing, escalating sanctions and treatment to help substance abusers break the cycle of addiction and the crime that accompanies it. *[[Mental health court]]s: Mental health courts link offenders who would ordinarily be prison-bound to long-term community-based treatment. They rely on mental health assessments, individualized treatment plans, and ongoing judicial monitoring to address both the mental health needs of offenders and public safety concerns of communities. *[[Domestic violence court]]s: Specialized domestic violence courts are designed to improve victim safety and enhance defendant accountability. They emerged as problem-solving courts in the 1980s and 1990s in response to frustration among victim advocates, judges and attorneys who saw the same litigants cycling through the justice system. *[[Problem-solving courts in the United States|Problem-solving courts]]: Problem-solving courts address the underlying problems that contribute to criminal behavior and are a current trend in the legal system of the United States. There were over 2,800 problem-solving courts in 2008, intended to provide a method of resolving the problem in order to reduce recidivism. *[[Restorative justice in social work|Restorative justice]]: Restorative justice uses dialogue to address the harm that has been done rather than relying solely on jail time as a means of justice. *[[Ankle monitor|Electronic Monitoring]]: Electronic monitoring is a device that individuals under house arrest or parole are often required to wear. At timed intervals, the ankle monitor sends a radio frequency signal containing location and other information to a receiver. If an offender moves outside of an allowed range, the police will be notified. *[[Deferred prosecution|Fines/Probation]]: A deferred prosecution agreement is a voluntary alternative to adjudication in which a prosecutor agrees to grant amnesty in exchange for the defendant agreeing to fulfill certain requirements. Fulfillment of the specified requirements will then result in dismissal of the charges. *[[Diversion program]]s: A diversion program in the criminal justice system is a form of sentencing and such programs are often run by a police department, court, a district attorney's office, or outside agency designed to enable offenders of criminal law to avoid criminal charges and a criminal record.
===Recidivism prevention===
[[Recidivism]] prevention takes place during incarceration and after release back into society. Its purpose is to reduce the risk of an individual reoffending and eventually returning into the prison system. National rates of recidivism over the last three decades have remained relatively steady at approximately 43 percent.<ref>{{cite book|title=State of Recidivism April 2011 The Revolving Door of America’s Prisons|date=April 2011|publisher=The Pew Center on States|page=2|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/uploadedFiles/wwwpewtrustsorg/Reports/sentencing_and_corrections/State_Recidivism_Revolving_Door_America_Prisons%20.pdf}}</ref> The recommendations provided by the "Report of the Re-Entry Policy Council" coordinated by the "Council of State Governments" reflect the opportunities available for action by entities interested in reducing recidivism. According to the report, there are steps policy makers or practitioners should complete in order to ensure successful programs, such as collaboration, proper funding, system integration, and educating the public. The report also states that policy makers must also consider additional programming needs for incoming offenders, including intake procedures, physical and mental health care, drug treatment, and vocational training. Finally, the report emphasizes the need to address changes in social service delivery, such as housing, workforce development, treatment programs, and mental and physical healthcare systems.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schrantz|first=Dennis|title=Coordinating Community Development: The Heart of the Michigan Prisoner ReEntry Initiative|journal=Corrections Today Magazine|date=April 2007|volume=69|issue=2|pages=42–49|publisher=http://www.aca.org/}}</ref>
==== Prison reform ====
Prison reform seeks to advocate for programming that gives offenders the tools they need for success. Physical and mental health, drug treatment, and educational and vocational programming give offenders the opportunity to begin the process of returning to their communities to become contributing members before they leave the facility.
==== Prisoner reentry initiatives ====
{{See also|National Criminal Justice Association#Prisoner Reentry|l1=Prisoner reentry}}
The overall purpose of such programs is to provide options, support, and opportunities for prisoners returning home into communities. The goal of preventing crime and reducing recidivism is attained through support programs including vocational and educational programs that provide returning citizens with the skills necessary to succeed in their reintegrated lives. The programs typically start by assessing strengths and risk factors through assessments when offenders begin their sentences, effective support and a plan for success that includes community support, and different strategies to help remediate skill and social deficiencies typically experienced by returning citizens.<ref>Washtenaw Prisoner Re-Entry Program.http://washtenawprisonerreentry.org/contactus.htm</ref>
== Juvenile confinement rates on steady decline ==
A study published by the Pew Institute found that there has been a significant decline in at least 37 states for juvenile commitment and violent crime arrest rates between 1997 and 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Latest Data Show Juvenile Confinement Continues Rapid Decline|url=http://www.pewstates.org/news-room/press-releases/latest-data-show-juvenile-confinement-continues-rapid-decline-85899480842#four|publisher=The Pew Charitable Trust State and Consumer Initiatives|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> These decreases in juvenile commitments can be a result of many different factors, including unique programs like the Ohio RECLAIM (Reasonable Equitable Community and Local Alternatives to the Incarceration of Minors) program. This program provides financial incentives that encourage juvenile courts to find and develop community based strategies and programs options that seek to meet the needs of juvenile offenders or at risk offenders.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ohio Reclaim|url=http://www.dys.ohio.gov/dnn/Community/ReclaimOhio/tabid/131/Default.aspx|publisher=Ohio Department of Youth Services|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> This program works to focus the most critical resources for the most serious offenders, such as those committing violent crimes and the most serious of offenses, while encouraging courts to look into community and restorative program placements for the youth who commit crimes not fitting such severe categories. As a result, Ohio has seen a significant decrease in institutional crowding and an 80% decrease in Department of Youth Services (DYS) caseloads from its peak in 1997 to 2012.

[[Marine biology]] | head = Ivan Dekeyser | endowment = [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]], [[Aix-Marseille University]] | debt = | num_members = | subsidiaries = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former_name = Endoume Laboratory | city = [[Marseille]] | country = France | coor = {{coord|43.2772|5.3771|type:landmark_region:FR|display=inline,title}} | address = Chemin Batterie des Lions | website = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Marine Station of Endoume''' is an [[oceanography]] and [[marine biology]] research institute located in [[Marseille]] (France). It was founded in 1882 by [[Antoine-Fortuné Marion]] (1846–1900). It is today one of the sites for the joint research unit IMBE{{Cite web|url=https://www.imbe.fr/|title=IMBE website|website=|dead-url=}}(Mediterranean Institute of marine and terrestrial Biodiversity and Ecology) hosting research teams from [[Aix-Marseille University]] and the [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]]. == History == The first [[marine biology]] laboratory in France outside Paris was founded in [[Marseille]] in 1869. The project to build a marine station in [[Marseille]] was initiated by its director [[Antoine-Fortuné Marion]] in 1872 and accepted in 1882. The station was built between 1883 and 1889, on the site of an old artillery battery in the neighbourhood of [[Endoume]]{{Cite journal|last=Marion|first=A.-F.|year=1897|title=La Station zoologique d’Endoume-Marseille|journal=Revue générale internationale scientifique, littéraire et artistique|volume=14|pages=179–198}}. The first scientific studies started in the summer of 1889. In 1891, the first public aquarium in Marseille opened at the marine station; in 1894, a marine natural reserve was created right in front of the marine station{{Cite journal|last=Romano|first=R.|year=1996|title=Histoire d’une station marine à Marseille : origine, naissance, développement (1869–1983)|journal=Master thesis, Université Aix-Marseille 1}}. A-F Marion was director of the station until his death in 1900. [[File:Antoine Fortuné Marion 1897.JPG|thumb|G. Gastine and [[Antoine-Fortuné Marion]] in a laboratory at the marine station of Endoume in 1897.]] === Directors === {|class="wikitable" |- !
